description:
A compound of the sources of be- +â€ come.
From Middle English becomen, bicumen, from Old English becuman (â€œto come (to), approach, arrive, enter, meet with, fall in with; happen, befall; befitâ€), from Proto-Germanic *bikwemanÄ… (â€œto come around, come about, come across, come byâ€), equivalent to be- (â€œabout, aroundâ€) +â€ come. Cognate with Scots becum (â€œto come, arrive, reach a destinationâ€), North Frisian bekommen, bykommen (â€œto come by, obtain, receiveâ€), West Frisian bikomme (â€œto come by, obtain, receiveâ€), Dutch bekomen (â€œto come by, obtain, receiveâ€), German bekommen (â€œto get, receive, obtainâ€), Swedish bekomma (â€œto receive, concernâ€), Gothic ğŒ±ğŒ¹ğŒµğŒ¹ğŒ¼ğŒ°ğŒ½ (biqiman, â€œto come upon one, befallâ€). Sense of "befit, suit" due to influence from Middle English cweme, icweme, see queem.

verbs.description: become (third-person singular simple present becomes, present participle becoming, simple past became, past participle become or (rare, dialectal) becomen)

entries.meaning: (copulative) begin to be; turn into. [from 12th c.]
examples: She became a doctor when she was 25.
The weather will become cold after the sun goes down.
The sense â€˜state or process of bearing fruitâ€™ has become imposed on fruition as the 20c. proceeded.

entries.meaning: (copulative) To come about; happen; come into being; arise. [from 12th c.]
examples: What became of him after he was let go?
It hath becomen so that many a man had to sterve.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be proper for; to beseem. [from 13th c.]
examples: He was hatted, booted, overcoated, and umbrellaed, as became a person who was about to expose himself to the night and the storm on an errand of charity  [â€¦]

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of an adornment, piece of clothing etc.: to look attractive on (someone). [from 14th c.]
(intransitive, obsolete) To arrive, come (to a place). [9thâ€“18th c.]
